body:
Thanks for the report! It goes to show that we're not using the OSGi metadata ourselves. Otherwise, this wouldn't have been broken for so long.

I ran a git bisect and the first bad commit was 6b34cdd0efea18143cd415b1530b050b9074d316, updating bnd from 6.4.0 to 7.0.0.

Looks like this is due to a [new feature](https://bnd.bndtools.org/instructions/noimportjava.html) introduced in that version.

Does Eclipse Equinox not support [OSGi Core R7](https://docs.osgi.org/specification/osgi.core/7.0.0/framework.module.html#framework.module-execution.environment)?

Removing those directives now could be considered a breaking change since other users with different OSGi runtimes might rely on them.

@bjhargrave Do you have any insight here?

Importing `java.*` packages is no longer invalid with the R7 Core specification. It does require the OSGi framework implementation supports R7 Core and also that you are using Java 9 or later (Java 9 added the reflective API which the OSGi framework implementation needs in order to know what `java.*` packages are present at runtime).

One "solution" would be for JUnit to add [`-noimportjava=true`](https://bnd.bndtools.org/instructions/noimportjava.html) to its bnd configuration. This prevents bnd from ever importing `java.*` packages.

> Java 9 added the reflective API which the OSGi framework implementation needs in order to know what `java.*` packages are present at runtime

bnd will check for this at build time, but with a library like JUnit, you cannot assume the same  (or later) version of Java is used at build time and runtime. Since JUnit is probably using the most current Java release at build time, bnd's heuristics determined importing `java.*` was safe. But this will not be the case for all possible users of JUnit, so adding the `-noimportjava=true` bnd configuration is appropriate.

We're using this on Java 8. The problem showed when trying to upgrade Equinox from 3.18 to 3.22. For some reason different versions of the Equinox launcher are used for different test fragments in our workspace (1.3 vs. 1.6). Those run with 1.6 work ok. Those launched with 1.3 fail with the errors above.

@bjhargrave The upcoming 6.0 release will have a Java 17 baseline. IIUC, you're saying that we can safely keep this feature enabled for 6.0 but should remove it for 5.x which has a Java 8 baseline, correct?

Why does bnd use the Java runtime as its heuristic rather than the Java compatibility that gets written to OSGi metadata?
@axeluhl Would it be possible to update the Equinox launcher you'rr using to 1.6 everywhere in your workspace?

Yes, I hope this will be possible. I think I may have found the reason some fragments run their tests with a slightly different configuration. There was a <repository> configuration with p2 layout declared in our root pom.xml that pointed to an ancient "luna" Eclipse release. This may have left Tycho with a choice: either use the target platform-specific Equinox 3.22 with the 1.6 launcher, or default to the old 3.9 Equinox from the Luna environment with its 1.3 launcher.

I have removed this legacy repo definition and hope this works around the issue for us.

Thanks for looking into this!

I would recommend you use `-noimportjava=true` in 5.x and 6.0. 

The reason support for importing of `java.*` was added in R7 Core was Java 9's JPMS which meant you could not know _a priori_ what java packages would be present at runtime like you could with Java SE 8 (for example). Pre R7 Core, a bundle would express a requirement on the `osgi.ee` namespace which indicated the bundle's expectations of what java packages it would possibly use. With R7 Core (and Java 9 at runtime), the bundle can specify the exact java packages it uses via Import-Package. For this to work, both the Java runtime must be Java 9 or later and the OSGi framework implementation must support R7 Core.

It sounds like for 6.0, you will require Java 17 at runtime. But I am not sure your bundles have any requirements on R7 Core (for example, import package of org.osgi.framework) since your bundles don't directly interact with the OSGi framework. So unless all your bundles will be importing `org.osgi.framework;version=[1.9,2)`, they can work on pre-R7 Core OSGi frameworks which do not understand importing of `java.*` packages. So not importing `java.*` packages makes your bundles more useful to consumers. And if your bundles only use java packages from the `java.base` module, then the java packages in that module is always present. I would guess most of your users will have the `java.se` module present which will contain all the java packages your bundles would use.

In hindsight, the default value of `-noimportjava` should probably have been `true` since most users will not need the fine grained support of importing individual java packages because their bundles will need to run on JPMS systems with a small subset of the "standard" SE modules.

> Why does bnd use the Java runtime as its heuristic rather than the Java compatibility that gets written to OSGi metadata?

It may be the way you suggest. I don't work on Bnd any more, so my memory fades...

rename.from: MANIFEST.MF contains illegal Import-Package: header for java.* packages
rename.to: Remove java packages from OSGi Import-Package directives
